reviewText: Both are great movies and i'm hoping this year both get a nice treatment, they should be Special Editions!
Title: Bram Stoker's Dracula/Mary Shelley's Frankenstein - Collector's Box Set

reviewText: Francis Ford Coppola's 1992 version of "Bram Stoker's Dracula" and Kenneth Branagh's 1994 "Mary Shelley's Frankenstein" are classics in their own right. Now, for the first time, these two faithful adaptations of the classic Gothic horror novels are available together for your ultimate viewing pleasure. Though this set hasn't been released yet, I have both of these great films (one on DVD-damn shame that it is only available in full screen and with no special features apart from the trailers [one for the feature film itself, the other two for "Much Ado About Nothing" and "Awakenings"] and the other on VHS). See my reviews on both films and the novels on which they are based. "Mary Shelley's Frankenstein" is rated PG for some violence. "Bram Stoker's Dracula" is rated PG-13 for some violence and brief sensuality/nudity.
summary: Two Great Films-One Hell Of A Deal. "Love Never Dies." "Be Warned. It's Alive." FFC And KB SUCCEED TREMENDOUSLY.
Title: Bram Stoker's Dracula/Mary Shelley's Frankenstein - Collector's Box Set

reviewText: Excellent movie and it adds to our already great thriller/mystery collection.  Received the dvd well before the expected date and watched it the first night. DVD is in great shape with vivid and sharp picture and sound. Excellent and professional service!
Title: Bram Stoker's Dracula/Mary Shelley's Frankenstein - Collector's Box Set

reviewText: I agree with the kid who wrote the last review.  These are exceptionally well done films and are very faithful to the novels. The performances are all exceptional (save for some of Winona Ryder's British accent in Dracula)with perfect casting. I also have the same complaints : 'Where are the special features?' and 'Why is Frankenstein in FULLSCREEN only? Why must studios screw good movies over in just Fullscreen (Moonstruck)? Couldn't it just as easily been widescreen or both(also Moonstruck)?' And yes, Dracula does need a new menu doesn't it?P.S.- I highly reccomend the film WOLF, just as the kid who wrote the last review did. It is sleek and intelligent (just like the box says!) and is also filled with exceptional performances.
Title: Bram Stoker's Dracula/Mary Shelley's Frankenstein - Collector's Box Set

reviewText: The "Dracula" video seemed to adhere quite closely to the Bram Stoker writing, with only a few variations.  I enjoyed this movie particularly to see the acting expertise of Gary Oldman. Hard to believe this was the same man that was the crooked DEA cop in "Leon,The Professional".In the same "vein" I very much enjoyed "Mary Shelly's Frankenstein", although I did not read this book. Robert DiNiro was excellent in the role, and the special effects in the laboratory was unbelievable. I think one critic said it was "Visually stunning" as to the landscape where it was filmed. The Swiss Alps, I believe. Parts of this movie were quite gory, but not to the point of turning away. I found the ending of this story very moving and the movie well worth watching.Neither of these movies are the same as the Dracula & Frankenstein flicks of the late 30's and 40's. Seen 'em all.  R.E.W.
Title: Bram Stoker's Dracula/Mary Shelley's Frankenstein - Collector's Box Set

reviewText: My review of these films is definitely in the minority.  They are not films I'd watch a second time.  The Lugosi and Karlof versions I have watched at least 10 times -- they are so much better.Coppola's Dracula is visually entertaining, with a different twist on the story -- now it's a love story spread across the centuries.  Okay, I'll play along.  The acting, as noted in other reviews, leaves much to be desired.  Gary Oldman as Dracula just doesn't cut it -- never in this film do you believe he could attract Winona Ryder.Branagh's Frankenstein is really his attempt at doing everything in the film (direct, star, re-write the script) and doing nothing well.  Casting De Niro as Frankenstein's monster was another blunder.  Also, Branagh is first a teenager, then a college student, then a married man in his 30's -- but he doesn't physically change one bit.  He looks basically the same at each period of his life.Both films could have lost a half hour of the script and not affected their story lines.
Title: Bram Stoker's Dracula/Mary Shelley's Frankenstein - Collector's Box Set
